review_title: Not the best and certainly not supportive!
pros: I’m not sure there are any!
cons: Micro-management, not able to use initiative. Poor pay, poor physical working conditions! Management seem to be of the opinion that the administrators do nothing, but they’re the ones that are getting everything done for very poor pay and certainly no real encouragement or support. Unrealistic expectations from management. Pay does not meet living wage levels.

job_title: Recovery Worker in City of Westminster, England
pros: The company took mental well being seriouse we had wellbeing days where we get half a day to just do something towards our well-being, the roles were challenging however this is the nature of the role I was in For me another major con was me being a Muslim I have to pray Friday prayers in a mosque and they really respected this and really respected my culture and I felt as though I could be myself within the company
cons: Sometimes too much politics within some of the workplaces The manager I had was very harsh and toxic in trying to help me improve my performance I basically felt forced out of the company because she no longer had use for me

review_title: Learnt lots and was supported to progress quickly

cons: Low salary for the amount of work involved in the role.

cons: There wasn't much support or guidance in relation to the expectations of the role, and very little career progression opportunities

job_title: Support Worker in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: Supported living you administer medication and as a support worker you learn new skills .Manager looks into all complaints , caring and fair .
cons: Old staff who do not like to try new ways of working.

pros: There is focus on Staff Wellbeing
cons: There are constant changes at times

job_title: Support Worker in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: Meals provided and that’s the only positive.
cons:
Where to start…
No official break. You get a ‘working break’ eating with the service users but due to the pandemic this doesn’t happen now. So quickly eat your lunch in 5 minutes or less. Unless you smoke you won’t get a break. 

Most smokers in the company abuse the smoking policy and go out constantly. 

Staff team are very clicky and talk about everyone. 

Complaints and suggestions to management never get sorted unless your teachers pet. Complained about bad support workers who are lazy, rude and generally poor carers and nothing gets done. 

Tried talking about flexible working due to my disabled family member and I got refused this request. Whereas other staff have flexible working and have no reason to. 

The service users are the only good thing about this job. Loved caring for them and their is some lovely characters. Shame most staff are only here for their mates and not to care. 

Overall don’t bother working for this company. Pay is rubbish. Even if you do every favour on gods green earth and work your butt of no one is bothered. Best off elsewhere.

job_title: Senior Quality Advisor in Manchester, England
pros: Worked with some great people.
cons:
Too much paper based work. 
Bullying by managers goes unaddressed. 
Senior managers are all from substance misuse background, not good for mental health or learning disability services.

pros:
Being able to help others was really rewarding. 
Keyworkers were great at what they did and looked out for each other.
Despite the terrible management, they did care about their clients.
Management do make sure you leave on time.
cons:
The job was not what was advertised - The role was a key workers role.
Misleading information on the job description.
Conflicting directions from management.
Isolated from other members of the team.
Denied training opportunities.
Incredibly high turnover of staff.
Gaslighting.
Terrible IT systems.
Very clearly I was managed out.
Unable to challenge management.
Unrealistic workload.
Blame culture.
I was employed to support a senior member of the team but was told they had no time to train me. I was then denied any opportunity to speak to them as they were too busy. I could not do my role when I was not allowed to even speak to the person I was there to support.

review_title: Shocking the pandemic has not recovered in care work

Very social job
Average pay
Pair holidays
I don’t think they’re a bad company there just understaffed and need committed staff.
cons: They basically need true caring reliable staff that ain’t gonna come in and try there best to make a hard situation worse. I think it’s to easy to jump from care job to care job! Try stick where you are and build and make a difference.

pros: I enjoy my job, supporting people, Turning Point is a good place to work, with a good team to work with they have helped me develop in my role i am learning more about the company which really cares about its staff. My manager is very supportive too.

job_title: Human Resources Manager in Manchester, England
pros: Great teams and work ethic

pros:
We had a good department which got on SMT's nerves. Laughter, hard work, integrity was what our manager told us to keep going, and we did until we got flushed out.

Got to support many good front-line workers.
cons: The senior management team are all for bullying anyone and everyone who doesn't fit into their ways of doing things.  They've got away with things for far too long and there's little wonder the culture of bullying that exists at head office is also spread across the sites.  I've never worked in a place so bad before and won't ever do so again.  Having a couple heading key departments in a commercial firm is not allowed, so why is it allowed in this firm?  Having a Lord as the head of Turning Point has been a disaster as the bullying culture is all down to him.   If you value your career, but aren't prepared to compromise on your morals like my old boss wasn't, then don't go anywhere near this firm.

pros: worthwhile enjoyable good team positive impact
cons: poor pay mandatory night shifts

review_title: Worst Work Experience of My Life - Avoid at all costs
pros: Staff and community partners were wonderful.
cons: Really incompetent voluntary sector  managers and directors, playing at being business leaders. CEO who lacks accountability and an aggressive HR department. My director was typical voluntary sector box ticker  didn't have a clue how to get the best out of people and felt it OK to lie to commissioners, if projects were not going well. The word collaborative working was all over the initiative but he failed to grasp what this actually meant in real terms.  This was Wall Street ethics from a charity who was try to 'transform communities'. A project I joined which had been in limbo for two years, when I  joined it moved forward very quickly and partners and stakeholders commented how relieved they were I had arrived. Flexible working was required for myself as I was a single parent living in another city, but was not given in real terms and used against me to build a case to sack me. They did it before six weeks probation was up.  I wish I had taken them to a tribunal.  This was the first time in my working life I had ever experienced discrimination in the workplace, I now know why we have policy's in place to penalise it. They guy is now a CEO of another charity, who of course will have no knowledge of his prior work tactics.

job_title: Recovery Worker in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: It's okay, not too bad.
cons: Not the worst, not the best.

pros: Friendly environment, inclusive of new ideas
cons: Lack of supervision, no incremental wage increase.

job_title: Recovery Coordinator in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Work community and friendly staff
cons: Lack of training and resources

pros: flexible work timings, good team, supportive managers
cons: can be exhausting, 12 hour shifts

job_title: Substance Misuse/Recovery Worker in London, England
pros: I love how supported I feel.
cons: I feel working from home can be isolating

job_title: Recovery Worker in Slough, Berkshire, South East England, England
pros: The clients are why most people stay
cons: Terrible treatment of staff by those in senior management, poor pay. Inadequate training, high turnover of staff.

job_title: Support Worker in Royal Leamington Spa, England
pros: Good place to work, friendly
cons: There is nothing wrong with it

pros: It is a charity organisation set up for the community good with some decent staff services and service users.
cons: Mismanagement of the charity funds is the norm and the leadership pay themselves a massive amount of money to sit around planning the exit of staff who are honest  and pay the staff who do the donkey work next to nothing. I watched people cry a lot at Turning Point and it's all due to the management.  We had loads of bullying reported to us, the bullies were always promoted to lead and the bullied person would be sacked.  Unethical place to work and it's so sad.

pros: I must say this is truly one of the best organisations I have worked for, I have always been impressed by the incredibly supportive culture of ‘Turning Point’, and it’s focus of staff wellbeing, especially during the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, which has been a very difficult time, for all those who work in health and social care. The most enjoyable part of the role is supporting service users, and being able to make a positive difference in there lives, and help them start on a journey of recovery. Turning Point is one of the few organisations that truly abide by its values especially the value that states ‘We believe that everyone has the potential to grow, learn and make choices’. I am looking forward to being able to continually grow and develop in my role, as I feel ‘Turning Point’ gives me the ability to do that. During my short time with ‘Turning Point’, I feel I have been nurtured and been able to grown in confidence by a supportive management. Thank you for the opportunity.
cons: IT equipment is a bit dated, could do with an upgrade.

pros: Non what so ever the management are complete demons! Come down and have a go and say that they regret taking on the home
cons: What can I say...... well let's start with the top down shall we!! Turning point are not a caring company oops sorry charity! The home they've just got through tender is a nurse run supported living service now I can understand that they don't deal with nurses but Jesus Christ there's no need what so ever to treat them like their dirt!!! They've come down repeatedly saying that if they new it was a nursing style home then they would never of taken it on and there's not much point in us coming down at the moment as we can't help! What sort of an attitude is that to have about a disability home!! Management (or lack of!!) Only stay for a few weeks to a month or so saying turning point are a bad company get out while you can!

pros: I you have nothing nice to say...
cons: An utterly contemptible, shameless company that treats its employees like a commodity rather than human beings. They may have so called compassion for their clients but have a collective heart of stone when it comes to treating their staff as human beings. I had to resign due to work related stress due directly from managerial incompetence. They had made childish errors in my salary which meant I was overpaid. After nearly a month of failed attempts to speak to an individual within HR and payroll, I was informed that the whole of my last months’ salary would be taken for the overpayment, even though I had made an offer of setting up a repayment scheme with them. Thank you Turning Point for ruining my family’s Christmas. Due to their combined incompetence and miss management of funds, I endure the most of your mistakes

pros:
Personally I have been respected and trusted to do my job. I have been given opportunities to develop and build on the good things that TP has to offer.
I have faith in my line manager and I feel that's returned.
Things are better than before. I am able to feel confident about voicing an opinion even if it goes against the grain. I feel listened to 
I have had a good experience working for TP and enjoy the challenge .
cons:
Sometimes great ideas and iniatives aren't always executed well. 
As much as I understand why this can't happen in many areas but the pay for front line staff isn't good. 
I don't feel nurture enough talent.

review_title: Very poor staff care and too much focus on corporate interest for the people at the top to make money
pros:
Passionate staff (at first!)
A good place to gain experience and then move on to something better if you truly want to make a difference and not just make managers more wealthy
cons:
Management are completely disconnected from front-line work and staff
A massive corporation that seems to have forgotten why it was created (to help people - not make money!)
Horrendous pay 
Senior managers are happy to lie to your face when discussing important things

pros: Turning Point are a very modern company to work for. The staff work incredibly hard and are often rewarded for hard work by Turning Point itself. Lots of area for personal and professional development - they have kindly funded my degree. A modern outlook to Substance Misuse services that go above and beyond for patients and service users. Work / Life balance is great, and managers help you to manage this appropriately.  I'd recommend healthcare workers working here if you would like a change and a positive challenge from traditional nursing jobs!!!
cons: 'People Point' services probably need reviewing. It is a confusing system for some, and often calculates annual leave hours incorrectly. I manage to navigate it, but it can be tricky. This isn't a major issue and the only 'Con' I can think of!

review_title: Do not work there if you validate integrity
pros: Leading a small team means I could get my hand dirty and learn new systems for my new job.
cons: If you are not protected by your manger then you are gone.  The leaders there are like use car salesman and there is nothing anybody can do about it.   The last honest manager went in 2013, walked out of the office in dishonour.  If you would like to learn new skills then go to Turning Point but wash your back because they will try to stab you many times.

pros: Turning Point do some great work and you definitely feel like you are contributing to something positive. The contract terms are fairly generous. They have some great managers and also some great staff. When you are left to get on with your job, and all is running smoothly, it is a great place to work.
cons: Staff who leave are not replaced, leaving others to take up the shortfall. As soon as something slides out of place, the whole service, and the frontline staff who run it, are left to flounder, which is damaging to employees and unfortunate for service users.

job_title: Support Worker in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: The support workers are good at what they do & they keep the business going.
cons:
Just when you think things cant get worse, they do and they do week on week. The staff have no motivation or support from managment. There are safeguarding problems which are swept under the carpet and forgotten about. If you report anything you are classed as a gossip or troublemaker. They would rather old staff with experience left and take on new staff just to rid them of 'thorns in the side' of the manager & Team Leaders. They take on family members constantly and also re-employ those that have previously been dismissed. 

If we are still open in 12 months time it will be a miracle.

pros: Going out on day trips with the service users as its free. I also work with some brilliant people and have made some friends for life.
cons: My manager is the most vile woman i have ever met! She has no people skills whatsoever, she has got a select few favourite staff and makes work a dream for them, but treats everyone else like something shes stepped in! She spends the majority of her working days outside smoking with her favourite staff. She hasnt got a clue how to do her job and puts the extra workload on the project workers! Pay is terrible for the job you do, 7.21 an hour while they pay 10 an hour to NHS tupe staff who do nothing but lick the managers backside!! Nothing you do is ever good enough!

review_title: Unethical sick pay policy and terrible working conditions
job_title: Administrative in City of Westminster, England
pros: Training good and colleagues are inspiring
cons: They deduct the first two days of any sick period from your wages. This means if you have a long term condition this Health and Wellbeing Charity is not for you. I have anecdotal evidence only of people delaying tumour therapy to avoid being put on a trigger warning for taking time off in addition to the loss of pay. I lost four hundred pounds in one month for having flu and that was one of the first times sick in around 2.5 years. What that  means to me is 'look for another job' with a more ethical company which doesn't by its behavior shame the entire public sector.

review_title: Bullying unprofessional, inexperienced management. who lie brush serious safeguarding issues under the carpet, And have
pros: Can't think of any pros at the moment.
cons: Poor pay. Poor management. Works on a blame culture, Don't address issues such as safeguarding. They would rather brush under the carpet. But are happy to bully and victimise staff that whistle blow. Lack of people skills, Managers don't get to know staff or the individuals that they are supposed to be looking after. And because of of the management not knowing the individuals they tend to make some poor decisions. Not person centred at all.

pros: none unless you go out for the day with an individual for your sanity
cons: Rubbish company they pay NHS good hourly rates and their own staff peanuts basic 7.20 want blood.  The managers gossip all the time have no professional boundaries but are always pranging on about it.  They bully and walk around like they own the company, walk around with their noses stuck in the air as if they are important the company is not a charity and yet wittle on they are.  They dont care about anything but money the staff the people they support are their bread and butter.  The managers should all be sacked a terrible click they suck up and if you can do this and keep your mouth shut this is the company for you.

pros: The service users do make it worthwhile as most are appreciative of the help received. High Job satisfaction.
cons: Terrible management from the top. Staff often very stressed and overworked. High staff burn out and turnover. This was some time ago, I hope things have improved.

job_title: Support Worker in Sunderland, North East England, England
pros: Supporting service users, and Annual Leave. The more time spent away from the place the better!!!
cons: Words fail me I didnt think it was possible for this organization to get even worse. The staff are completely demoralized, safeguarding is a complete joke, and if you have any concerns dont even bother attempting to report any concerns as the Service Manager will immediately accuse staff of gossiping, Team Leaders arent much better, and nepotism is rife with their family members being taken on as support workers but completely bypassing the application & interview process. The place is a complete joke, god help the service users!!!!

pros: I had the unfortunate experience of working for turning point in one of their projects. During this time staff were bullied by the manager and worked in a state of distress. Supervision and work under this person was controlling and victimising. I cannot think of a single pro of working there. Poor clients were controlled by the managers whims and senior management did not take complaints seriously.
cons: unprofessional, abusive, bullying and hazardous to employee and subsequently client health and welfare. Avoid working for turning point at all costs. The do not know what they are doing, this manger thought they owned their staff and they were their personal property.

review_title: Do not TUPE over to this charity!
job_title: Drug/Alcohol Recovery Worker in Croydon, England
pros:
None.
None.
During the TUPE process the management were all smiles and positive. Once they took over the management had very little idea of the issues of the area. Experienced staff were treated poorly.
cons:
Unprofessional management. 
A one process fits all regime was enforced - 12 week recovery program for everybody. No account taken of social, mental, family, etc. issues. 
Totally focused on hitting 'targets'., including 95% of referred released prisoners to attend the clinic on the day of release! Management has never heard of lockdowns.
We lost the fact we were dealing with people.
Training was of poor quality 'in-house' Few opportunities to develop skills.

review_title: A rewarding role in a great place to work
job_title: Head of Talent Acquisition in London, England
pros: Autonomy to deliver and drive strategy. A highly supportive and engaging senior team. TP puts the people they support at the very heart of all they do and often in challenging margins.  You often have to wear more than one 'hat' but this allows you the stretch to deliver
cons: None  - the only challenge would be having to do more with less

review_title: Great organisation, working in difficult circumstances
pros: The most supportive, friendly organisation I have worked for, with really admirable aims. I have been allowed a lot of autonomy in my job and have developed a lot in my time here.
cons: Our funding is always a challenge, there is often not enough money to do the things we want to do and people do work hard. We don't have the advanced systems that some better off organisations have.

pros: None they don't believe in underlings
cons:
SMT are bullies who rule by fear. Use pip wholesale.
Think of stats and not patient's
Staff are treated as disposable and don't give them values
No motivation
Salary terrible
Get emails on Friday at 3pm saying this must be done by end of day or else.
Average 20 emails a day demanding.
Moral in London is so low that everyone is leaving apart from ANY who should
Their answer to sell being is to give 1 hour off a month, when you are forced to work extra each week.
This is a corporate business not a charity who just don't care
Would you trust a relative to an organisation like this?
They react when due a CAB visit, why are they not working properly in the first place.

review_title: Pros and cons more cons than pros

cons:
Bullying and when reported to management you are accused of gossiping 
Unorganised on paperwork 
Unorganised on rota 
Pay is rubbish with what is expected of you to do in your job role I have worked in care for over 4 years and never worked for a company like it 
Safeguarding is not 100 per cent 
High turnover of staff

pros:
Helping the service users
Going home at the end of the day
cons:
Where to begin there a quite a few.

Workmates over worked 
Pay is rubbish for the work that you do
Poor commucation from mangement
Bullying 
You raise issues and they arnt listened to
Mangement seam to take it out staff for there mistakes 
Rotas arnt done properly

job_title: Head of Development for Mental Health and Learning Disabilities in Manchester, England
pros: I worked in the mental health and learning disability business unit. The culture and ethos of the team from the MD to Support Worker was superb. The organisation is truly focussed and driven to provide the best possible support and look after its staff.  This is sadly becoming increasingly  rare in providers of care, support and recovery. I can’t recommend Turning Point enough to anybody loooking for a new role and looking for career development opportunities.
cons: I didn’t experience any downsides

review_title: Badly managed, with no regard to staff.
pros: Helping clients to move on with their lives.
cons: Salary, shift patterns, badly run.

pros: A company who will really develop you.  The job is very satisfying.  You get to help people everyday and that makes getting up in the morning much easier.  They pay is not stella but then you don't look for work in this industry because you want to be a millionaire.  It is, I think, fair.  A really amazing team of worker in my centre.
cons: Sickness Policy is horrible.

review_title: Most Management have no social care experience on the shop floor.
job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Lewes, England
pros: Service user contact good, and the project I worked on achieved a lot, based on the compassion and goodwill of employees.
cons: Awful and inhumane sickness policy. Appalling pay. Staff wellbeing should be a priority, and leads to greater productivity in the end.

pros: Good staff bulllied by bullying managers who copied their bully bosses at Head office. If you meet good boss, then you're lucky.
cons:
The place has got worsened over the years.  Staff bullying, lying, mismanagement, fake investigation, favouritism, giving the Mrs plum jobs to cover up things has never been worst and just like the Kid companies, in 2017 Turning Point will loose favor with all those people propping up Victor. Never has a company been reported to the authoritys so much with nothing beign done about them. 

If you are Tupe’d to Turning Point then resist like crazy.  If you are thinking of working at Turning Point, think again and be careful if you are a honest person or a half decent person or they backstab you.

pros:
No 1. It's not North Korea
No 2. There is no No 2
No 3. I have to meet the 20 word minimum
cons:
Honestly, don't know where to begin, a thorough review would result in an essay so I'll try and summarize my experience in brief bullet points which provide scope rather than focusing on all the specific things I witnessed / endured. Naturally, the below is a matter of opinion.

- Senior management are arrogant, and completely disconnected from the staff that work below them, either in the head office or nationally. Constantly in meetings, rude, don't even make an effort to communicate to those below them, when they do communicate its usually something condescending or rude. No effort made by them to make employees feel valued. e.g. No after work events or Christmas party. Meanwhile senior management socialise often.

- Pay is terrible. Mine was ok for the work, but those outside of London and or particularly within the care environment are on such a low salary its scandalous. Far below industry average. 

- Staff turnover is the highest I've seen anywhere. Don't bother to get to know anyone, they will probably be gone in a few months. I saw so many people come in go during my time. Staff are underpaid, demotivated. Pressure put on staff to perform at an unattainable standard for disgracefully low pay creates hostile work environment.

- Bullying.

- Absolutely zero career development opportunities. I asked several times to develop my skills in order to be a bigger asset to the organisation, requests were repeatedly ignored.

- Organisation is unjustifiably arrogant. 

- You just can't win. I don't wish to be too specific, but you will be chastised for one thing, then chastised again when you do the opposite. 

- Very little emphasis on the quality of care.

I never felt more professionally demotivated as I did during my time with this organisation. Leaving has made me immeasurably happier.

review_title: Overall the experience has been very food staff work together for the people we support

cons: Staffing in the local area is difficult there are lots of other similar establishments.

review_title: Do not work for turning point

cons: Poor management who blame workers for their own mistakes. No supervision. Back biting from the top down. The worst work experience in 45 in the work place.  Became depressed from a bullying incompetent line manager. No point in reporting this as top man a worse bully. So relieved to leave.
